Natal has been in the news lately; hosting several World Cup matches!","Nadal has also been in the news lately; losing several sets to a teenager! :-P","Great question Suhas Pai. (though it took me off on a tangent.  Ouch!)","Was this inspired from CGP Grey?"]

results.description:
Voter-verified paper audit trail (VVPAT) or verified paper record (VPR) is a method of providing feedback to voters using a ballot less voting system. 

A VVPAT is intended as an independent verification system for voting machines designed to allow voters to verify that their vote was cast correctly, to detect possible election fraud or malfunction, and to provide a means to audit the stored electronic results .

In 2014 general elections VVPAT was introduced in 8 of the 543 constituencies as a pilot project with one of them being in Karnataka .

Where ?

results.answer: It is at the border of Argentina and Brazil.  Situated between upper and lower Iguazu rivers, there are more than 275 waterfalls averaging more than 200 feet.  Thay are not the tallest in the world but widest, more than 8000 feet.  The largest of them is the "Devil's Throat" (Garganta del Diablo), nearly 280 feet tall.  The amount water dumped in a year is highest in the world, moe than Niagara.  Most of the falls are on the Argentinian side but there is also spectacular viewing spots from the Brazilian side as well, where a boardwalk can get you very close to some of them.

They got several responses, including one that turned out to be the one gifted to Honduras. The person in possession of this moon rock demanded 5 million dollars, and NASA requested a billionaire Ross Perot (founder of Perot Systems) to arrange for the cash.\n\nAt a Miami restaurant, where the transaction was supposed to take place, they seized the rock, on the grounds that it was illegally imported into the United States because the custom forms were not filled. The rock was subsequently re-gifted to the President of Honduras.","how did he lose it in the first place??","The gifted moon rocks are usually housed in museums, from where they are stolen. results.answer: Leap seconds
results.comments:
["Leap seconds","Yeah","This year will be one second longer than 2014. Scientists have announced that they’ll be adding an extra second, called a “leap second” to the UTC (coordinated universal time) clock on June 30 at 11:59:59.

That means the clock will read 11:59:60. This is because the Earth is moving a little slower than our super-accurate atomic clocks dictate, and it’s getting out of sync. In fact, while atomic time is constant, the Earth’s rotation is slowing down by around two thousandths of a second each day.

"The real simple explanation is the Earth is slowing down a little bit," Nick Stamatakos, the head of the Earth Orientate Parameters at the US Naval Observatory told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.","Are we supposed to adjust our clocks?? :D","will employers pay for that extra second?"]

results.answer: The battleship was Graf Spee, named after a German admiral. The statue is a solid brass figure of an eagle perched on the swastika weighing 700 pounds with a wingspan of 9 feet. A similar one was also on the Bismarck. It had sunk off the coast of Uruguay in shallow waters of only 30 feet. Privately salvaged in2006 it is stored in obscurity in a warehouse. But it is a political hot potato because Germany is concerned that it will further besmirch its image. Uruguay has the dubious distinction of sheltering many war criminals from Germany after the war. Not a happy situation for both countries

results.description:
All time favorite trivia I came across 
World War 2 ended following the atomic bombings at Hiroshima and Nagasaki . 
The selection of these 2 cities wouldn’t have been easier and with so many peoples’ life at stake .

Accordingly there were 4 choices in front of USA with Kyoto topping them all as the emperor lived there . 

However War secretary of USA at the time vetoed the selection of Kyoto for a particular reason and thus Hiroshima and Kokura became the primary targets .

Curse the weather , owing to the bad weather Nagasaki which was not even the list of 4 became the victim .
What remains as one of the hilarious things in the history is the reason behind war secretary Henry Stimson not preferring Kyoto as the primary target .

 Why ??

King George V visited India and attended Delhi Durbar in Royal regalia in 1911 with all the pomp and splendor.  A jewel studded crown was made specially for the occasion (now with the Tower of London collection) and called Imperial Crown of India had emeralds, rubies, sapphires and 6100 diamonds. He was an avid hunter just like Teddy Roosevelt, the American president who was fond of adventures like hunting and (more famously) navigating a branch of the Amazon - called River of Doubt - when he lost fifty pounds (he surely could afford to lose some) and almost died from malaria (and almost shot with poison arrows by the native river people).  George V ruled from 1910 to 1936.  The capital of British Empire in India was moved from Calcutta to New Delhi during his tenure.","Correction: Teddy Roosevelt was not an avid hunter. results.answer: Brahmi was the script used by Ashoka. Ironically, no one could read it and it soon became extinct, despite the fact that there were hundreds of rock edicts and stone pillars with writings were around for centuries. The indecipherable script was soon thought to be written by God Brahma (Z), and came to be called Brahmi script. The language was Prakrit, which is unrefined Sanskrit. Kharosthi was another related script used in North West India at the time of Bactrian Greek rule by successors of Alexander. James Prinsep was the name of the Brit who deciphered Brahmi script, circa 1836. In the inscriptions Ashoka had signed his name as Devanamapiya Piyadasi. That this was the same king as Ashoka was also surmised by Prinsep after examining text called Mahavamsha from Sri Lanka. Mahavamsha had the names of the hierarchy of the Maurya dynasty. Ashoka is mentioned in it as the grandson of Chandragupta Maurya. Prinsep was a genius who worked in Calcutta mint and had access to many antique coins with Brahmi letters.

The script is not Devanagari script, Vikram Hebbar, (which came into practice a thousand years later).","Brahmi or prakrit","Prakrit","Kharoshti?","Brahmi was the script used by Ashoka.  Ironically, no one could read it and it soon became extinct, despite the fact that there were hundreds of rock edicts and stone pillars with writings were around for centuries.  The indecipherable script was soon thought to be written by God Brahma (Z), and came to be called Brahmi script. The language was Prakrit, which is unrefined Sanskrit.  Kharosthi was another related script used in North West India at the time of Bactrian Greek rule by successors of Alexander.","Ah, my bad","Here is the rest of the answer:  James Prinsep was the name of the Brit who deciphered Brahmi script, circa 1836.  In the inscriptions Ashoka had signed his name as Devanamapiya Piyadasi.  That this was the same king as Ashoka was also surmised by Prinsep after examining text called Mahavamsha from Sri Lanka.  Mahavamsha had the names of the hierarchy of the Maurya dynasty.  Ashoka is mentioned in it as the grandson of Chandragupta Maurya.  Prinsep was a genius who worked in Calcutta mint and had access to many antique coins with Brahmi letters."]

Who are (X) and (Z)?

results.answer: Professor Pitchappan from Madurai University tested one Mr. Virumandi who belonged to the Kellar tribe of Kerala and found the gene M130 with an amino acid band and Y Chromosome unchanged from the first humans who migrated along the coast from South Africa to India 60,000 years ago. The gene could be seen in the entire tribe because of its scheduled caste and the practice of marriage between cousins. The migration could be traced to the Arabian peninsula and to Kutch in Gujarat as well.

results.description:
X is a meringue-based dessert named after the Russian ballet dancer Y. It is a meringue dessert with a crisp crust and soft, light inside. The dessert is believed to have been created in honour of the dancer either during or after one of her tours to Australia and New Zealand in the 1920s. The nationality of its creator has been a source of argument between the two nations for many years, but formal research indicates New Zealand as the source.

The dessert is a popular dish and an important part of the national cuisine of both countries, and with its simple recipe, is frequently served during celebratory and holiday meals. It is a dessert most identified with the summer time, but is eaten all year round in many Australian and New Zealand homes.

results.answer: The island's name is abbreviated as St. Barts or St. Barth. Columbus named it after his brother Bartolomeo. Old Bartolomeo was no saint, however. Many of the islands and cities "discovered" by Columbus were named after saints in the Caribbean (St. Thomas, St. John, St. Croix, Saint Martin, St. Kitts, St. Vincent, and cities like San Juan, Santa Domingo). The French first claimed it in 1648 and later gave it to Sweden in 1784 in a trade agreement. Swedes established the Swedish West India Company. During the twelve years of Napoleonic Wars (1803 - 1825) the island thrived but later its declined. France bought it back in 1878. The French might have added the prefix "Saint" to Bartolomeo's name. The Swedes established the city Gustavia and named it for their King Gustav III. Today it is a beautiful resort island favored by many celebrities who own property there.

results.answer:
GPS! GNSS isn't its old name; GNSS (global navigation satellite system) is a generic term used to describe this technology.

GPS (and all the satellites that make up this system) are still owned by the US. Earlier, they used to degrade the strength of the signal meant to be used by civilians, by a policy known as Selective Availability. Clinton removed this policy, but certain GPS features are still available only to the US Military. The US can technically decide to block out GPS for civilian usage if they want, so other countries have been building their own GPS-like systems. Galileo from the EU is one of them, IRNSS by India is another. Neither of them have worldwide courage so far though.

results.answer: Brazil.
results.comments: ["Mexico ?","Canada?","Or maybe its Brazil for work in the coffee plantations ?","Brazil.","Brazil ws t country tht importd most no of negro slaves...","Brazil it is.  They were originally brought for work in sugar plantations, later diversified for mining and coffee.  In the 19th century alone more than a million slaves were brought in.  Slave trade had started in the early 16th century, much earlier than North America (where it started in 1619).  In 1825 people of African origin accounted for 56% of the population.","Not imported but India has highest number of slaves .. Sitting in front of computers for 10+ hours a day ..","A big difference between the slaves of North and South America was that the Brazilian slaves, though worked hard (average life expectancy of a young male was 23 years!), could secure manumission easily.  North American slave owners considered slaves as chattel but Brazilian slaves could buy their freedoms.  By 1872 three-quarters of blacks and mulattos of Brazil had been manumitted.","Why did North America become a model democracy whereas South America was full of despotic dictatorship?  Both continents were colonized by Europeans around the same time.  Yet the slaves in NA had a worse chance of getting freed (especially in the Southern United States, where they even fought a civil war after the emancipation proclamation by Lincoln).  What is the reason?","The people oppressing them","NA was colonised by the pilgrims who weren't controlled by a higher power (i.e the British Monarchy) but the other colonial powers had to answer to their ruling monarchs back in Europe.?","The pilgrims still were under the British monarchy.  It was only after 1776 Declaration of Independence that NA was unshackled.  Even after that the slaves had fewer rights in NA than in the dictatorships of SA.","The difference is that NA gave people the right to own property.  Later when the constitution was signed property rights, liberty and pursuit of happiness were carefully put in the document.  In SA, even (and especially) after the revolution of Bolivar, people were considered unworthy of holding property or having voting rights, and a few dictators controlled vast swathes of land and influence.  People did not have the right to vote, by design and idea of democracy never could take hold.  In NA property right was so inalienable that the slaves, who were considered as personal property (chattel) could not be relinquished to the government.  Most in the southern US considered emancipation proclamation as government overreach and infringement on property rights.  In SA where people had no sense of private property did not have the same sentiments about land ownership or chattel slaves.  Hence the slaves could buy their own freedom easily."]
results.description: We all know that North America was the bastion for slave trade for centuries, long after England had given up the practice.  Yet it is not the country that imported the highest number of slaves.  Name the country that imported the highest number of slaves.

results.answer: Language is Old Avestan. The earliest hymns revered by Zoroastrians are the Gathas. They are part of Yasna (yajna in Sanskrit). Gathas, which are hymns praising God Ahura Mazda, could only be understood by comparison to Sanskrit of Rig Veda as the grammar and meanings of many words are not known.
results.comments: ["The religion is probably Zorastrianism...","Zoroastrianism","Language is Pali?","I would say the religion is Buddhism, as far as I remember Pali was used around the time Buddhism came into picture and is still widespread, no idea about the texts ..","Zend Avesta, Avestan?","Close enough.  Language is Old Avestan.  The earliest hymns revered by Zoroastrians are the Gathas.  They are part of Yasna (yajna in Sanskrit). Gathas, which are hymns praising God Ahura Mazda, could only be understood by comparison to Sanskrit of Rig Veda as the grammar and meanings of many words are not known.","Yasna deals with rituals similar to Yajur Veda and the texts of Brahmanas.  Even the deities are the same.  The similarities are key to tracing Sanskrit and Avestan back to originating from Indo-Iranian languages and perhaps back to  Indo-European languages as well.","And what about the theory that Ahura is the India form of Asura and   Daevas  is the Sanskritized form of Devas?","The language of Rig Veda is unrefined Sanskrit.  At the time there  were spoken forms of Sanskrit like Pali and Prakrit.  Panini was responsible for refining Sanskrit, hence called Classic Sanskrit.  Panini was thought to have been a teacher in Takshshila - Taxila - in or around 5th century B.C. (?).","I think you are correct, Dayanand Prabhu.  Daevas (skt: devas) are not always given sanctimonious immunity in Zoroastrianism.  They also worship Ahura Mazda along with other ahuras (skt: asuras) and some are condemned to the seven regions of the earth forever.","Please visit www.bharatmataram.wordpress.com","Just curious, at what stage of evolution did humans invent language","That is a loaded question, Vigneshwar Shankar Poojar.  It is the most difficult question for linguists and archeologists to answer.  Homo sapiens have been around for two hundred thousand years and were capable of making sounds and communicate.  Human migration started out off Africa around 50,000 years ago and they were surely able to communicate.  Language diffusion happened because of migration or conquest, slowly at first, but increasing in rapidity as time went on.  But perhaps an organized language called Indo-Hittite developed in Anatolia (current day Turkey) after the Ice Age ended (around 12,000 years ago).  Perhaps about 8500 years ago.  This was followed by proto Indo-Eurpoean language, then leading to Indo-European language (Greek, Germanic, Celtic etc. also developed from the Indo European language). Later Indo-Iranian and Indo-Aryan languages developed.  Sanskrit and Avestan languages were the earliest Indo-European languages. Farming, herding and pastoral communities were well established when Rig Veda and Avesta were written.  As for accurate dates, your guess is as good as anyone's!","Warning: There are as many theories about origin of languages as there are spoken languages!","Just a an Addition. It is as much a field of anthropology as is of archaeology."]
results.description:
Vedic Sanskrit differs quite a bit from Classic Sanskrit (after its grammar was refined by Panini).  There is one language which closely resembles (and is almost indistinguishable as to its origin from) Vedic Sanskrit.  It is now no longer a spoken language but revered religious texts in the form of hymns exist.  The similarities between these two languages have helped in tracing the common ancestry of both.

What is the language and what is the religion?  What are the texts called?

In sand with just the right amount of dampness, capillary bridges—essentially microdroplets of water that bind grains of sand to one another through capillary action—form across the grains, which doubles the material's relative stiffness. results.description:
He was a lecturer in the Government College of Lahore.  In 1905 he was invited to preside over a student body meeting.  Instead of giving a speech he recited a song he had published the previous year.  The song praised the motherland, urging Hindus and Muslims to have tolerance for each other and live with a national identity of secular Hindustan.  It became an anthem for the Indian independence movement.  In the 1930's when Gandhi was in Yerawada jail in Pune, he was purported to have sung this ode to Hindustan a hundred times.  

The Muslim author of the song was a great believer in a Hindu-Muslim integrated society.  But two decades later he changed his view and in his presidential address to the Muslim League in Allahabad in 1930, he proposed a separate nation-state for Muslim majority in India.  He thus paved the way for the partition of Indian subcontinent after independence from the British.  

He even wrote another song in the same metre and rhyme as the original patriotic song.  In that song he renounced a secular homeland but claimed that Muslims belonged to the world community of Muslims.

Who was the author and what was the title of the song?  What was the name of the second song?

After recovering from a hypnotic daze listening to Shilpa Shetty speaking Kannada on TV during International Yoga Day (June 21), I switched to a movie channel and found that Father's Day is being celebrated on the same day and there was a Father's Day Special movie going on. Slightly bemused, I switched to a music channel only to be notified that World Music day is also on the same day.

Well, June 21, the day of the Summer Solstice, is also celebrated as World ______ Day, where _____ represents an animal. While this animal's anatomy is conducive to yoga poses, it is not well known at all for its musical abilities and it is generally regarded as an absentee father. 
However, zoos still capitalize this (yay capitalism!) by offering combos for Father's Day and _______ Day. What is ________?

results.description:
X made a statistical error in his experiment but nonetheless liked the result.  He was working on photons (and instead of four statistical possibilities he only accounted only for three) and the result truly fascinated despite the error.  He sent his paper with the error to reputed science journals of Europe.  Being an obscure Indian he was promptly ignored (like many other brilliant Indian scientists of his era).

He then sent his findings and the paper to Einstein, who cleaned it up a bit and presented it as two separate papers.  It was immediately noted by the Europeans because of Einstein's clout and reputation.  The finding was eventually called by the first initials of name of (X) and Einstein - (X)E___.

Since Nobel Prize is not given posthumously, X never received it but highly deserved it for his finding.  Advent of lasers in recent decades has rekindled interest in (X)E___.

Who is X and what is (X)E______?

results.description:
(A) were the main enemies of the Israelites during the Biblical times.  They are frequently mentioned in Genesis and Deuteronomy.   They had settled in Southwest part of current day Israel (and especially in the region of Gaza, which they called Minoah).

(B) was one of the Five Good Emperors of Rome in the second century.  He was an avid builder of many walls, gates, amphitheaters and promenades.  But he hated the Jews and transformed the Temple Mount in Jerusalem by building pagan Roman temple for Jupiter.  He even renamed Jerusalem as Aelia Capitolonia.

Out of hatred for the Jews (who had revolted) he not only banned circumcision but also banned anyone who was circumcised to enter the city.  He renamed the entire region (C) based on the name of the non Semitic people (A) as a reminder to the Jews who had fought with (A) for thousand years.

ID (A) and (B)

What was the name (C) he used based on (A) for the region?

X did the foundational work that led to the COBOL programming language. When retired from the U.S. Navy at age 79, X was the oldest active-duty commissioned officer in the service. She was a close associate of Vinobha Bhave and had fought in the non violent Swaraj movement of Gandhi.  She championed the cause of the poor, landless and Dalits along with her husband Shankaralingqm Jagannathan.  Krishnammal (b 1926) has spoken of how she discussed her fond memories of MLK with her son.  Krishnammal has established several Non-Govermental institutions, including Land for Tiller's Freedom (LAFTI) and is the recipient of many awards for the social work of a lifetime."]

results.answer: MK Gandhi is right. Like a lot of desis these days, 21 year old Gandhi was back then studying in London, and had to do the obligatory Euro trip. He didn't visit a lot of places due to budgetary concerns, but he came to Paris to see the Exhibition and the Eiffel Tower. In those days there was no Schengen Visa, so I am wondering if Gandhi had to apply for a separate French visa. He makes no mention about applying for a visa in any of his memoirs though. The above quote is from my favorite book "My experiments with truth". 41 years later, when he stepped foot in France again after taking part in the Round Table Conference, he was a celebrity and he was mobbed by people trying to get a glimpse of him.The next great exhibition was in Chicago in 1893. There was nothing they could build that could surpass or even match the magnificent Eiffel Tower. The organizers were sick with fear that Chicago would be overshadowed and branded as junior league in comparison. In the end Chicago was also known for its "first." The giant Ferris Wheel was invented (by George W Ferris, a bridge- builder from Pittsburgh) and was a grand attraction of the fair. It was also the first world fair to be electrified with Tesla's AC technology. Thomas Edison was very sour and upset that his DC technology lost the bid. Of course, Chicago fair was where Vivekanada introduced Hinduism (and himself) to the world.

results.description:
In 1890, X visited the Eiffel tower. In fact, he went to the top twice or thrice and had lunch at the restaurant at the top. However, he was not impressed and had some choice words to say about it. In fact, you would think that this was a monologue from the movie 'Fight Club':

""There is no art about the Eiffel Tower. In no way can it be said to have contributed to the real beauty of the Exhibition. Men flocked to see it and ascended it as it was a novelty and of unique dimensions. It was the toy of the Exhibition. So long as we are children we are attracted by toys, and the Tower was a good demonstration of the fact that we are all children attracted by trinkets. That may be claimed to be the purpose served by the Eiffel Tower."

Whom did the Eiffel tower fail to impress?

results.answer: X is Fado.
results.comments: ["X is Fado.","Fado"]
results.description:
X is a music genre which can be traced to the 1820s in Portugal. X is a form of music characterized by mournful tunes and lyrics, often about the sea or the life of the poor, and infused with a characteristic sentiment of resignation, fatefulness and melancholia (loosely captured by the word saudade, or "longing"). The music is usually linked to the Portuguese word saudade which symbolizes the feeling of loss. Famous singers of X include Amália Rodrigues, Dulce Pontes, Carlos do Carmo, Mariza,etc. On 27 November 2011, X was inscribed in the UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists. X typically employs the Phrygian Dominant scale also common in Middle Eastern and Flamenco music.
ID X.

results.answer:
It is the brightest of the trio of supermoons this summer.  Because it appears 16% larger and 30% brighter it is called extra-supermoon on August 10.  A slightly less impressive supermoon will present itself on September 9.  

Astronomical community calls this moon "perigee full moon" because in its full phase it is closest to the earth at 221,765 miles from earth in its elliptical orbit around the earth. (Perigee is when a heavenly body is closest to the earth).  

Next time perigee supermoon at the full phase will occur again in 2034.  Last time this happened was in March of 2011.

results.answer: Yes.  She is Alice Coachman, the first black American woman to win Olympic Gold medal in Track & Field (High Jump - 5 feet 6 1/8 inches, an olympic record) London in 1948.  She was the only American woman to win gold that year.  She was also the first American woman ever to win a track & field event.  She would have won more medals earlier if olympics of 1940 and 1944 were not cancelled because of WWII.  She died a few days ago at age 90.  She paved the way for future American women athletes (who have dominated Track & Field events.)  She was from the segregated America.  Jim Crow law had prevented her from having any formal training.  She did not even own shoes when she competed in high school events in both high jump and sprints.  Her town Albany, Georgia held a felicitation for her where the whites and blacks sat in separate sections, and the mayor did not shake her hands.  Blacks who gave her gifts identified themselves, whereas all the gifts that came from whites were anonymous!

results.answer: X is Mocha, a port city in Yemen. Mocha was a very prominent center for trading coffee beans back in the day. The English, Dutch, French, and Danish East Indian companies all had factories in Mocha and used the port for exporting coffee. Eventually, the Turks took over and the factories had to be closed down. Today, it is just another town in Yemen with not much economic significance attached to it. The moccacino, or the Cafe Mocha, is named after it. Y is Baba Budan, our very own sufi saint. He made several pilgrimages to Mecca and back, and on the way, he supposedly passed by Mocha and brought back coffee seeds to Chikmagalur where the first coffee estates sprung up. Of course, there is no concrete proof to this legend, so several other versions may exist.

results.description:
Just like Shannon, Ireland (if you remember the question), Gander, Newfoundland was one of the busiest International airport in the older days. In those days, transatlantic flights could not be completed in one leg and hence they used to stop at Gander for refuelling etc.

Today, Gander is a dying airport, since airplanes can cover larger distances, thus voiding its need. However, the facilities at Gander have not yet been demolished, and they were put to good use at one time in the 21st century, when reportedly hundreds of flights landed there. In fact, thousands of people were housed in Gander for a couple of days. When was that?

results.description:
X and his wife Y were a french couple who were designated Z. For 15 years, X served as a pastor in the French town of Le Chambon-sur-Lignon. In his preaching he spoke out against discrimination as the Nazis were gaining power in neighboring Germany and urged his Protestant Huguenot congregation to hide Jewish refugees from the Holocaust of the Second World War. From the beginning of the German occupation, the inhabitants of the village adopted a spirit of resistance, encouraged by their pastor, X and his assistant, Pastor Edouard Theis. Z is an honorific used by the State of Israel to describe non-Jews who risked their lives during the Holocaust to save Jews from extermination by the Nazis. Notable individuals who were honoured with Z were Oskar Schindler, Irena Sendler, Carl Lutz and others. 

ID X,Y and Z.

results.answer: Haifa is a city on the slopes of Mount Carmel in Northern Israel on its Mediterranean coast. The mausoleum belongs to the Báb, founder of Bábism, a precursor to Bahá'í faith. He claimed to be the Mahdi (Báb, literally means gate, identified himself as the gate - a messenger - to the hidden Twelfth Imam of the Shi'a faith). TheBáb (real name Sayyid Ali Muhammad Shirazi), aged 30, was executed by a firing squad for this crime in Persia in early 19th century. Bahá'u'lláh (Mírzá Ḥusayn -Ali Núrí) in late 19th century followed his principles in founding the Bahá'í Faith. He instructed his son to build the mausoleum for the Báb, whose remains were transferred there from Acre, a town in the plains below Mount Carmel. Bahá'u'lláh, who died in captivity was interred in a simple building surrounded by a beautiful garden in Acre (see picture).

results.answer: Steve Jobs

["Steve Jobs?","who is that","Apple Co-founder","I didn't know you were on first-name terms with him, but yes, it is Steve Jobs. Steve Jobs' biological father, Abdulfattah Jandali was born in the city of Homs. This wasn't a known fact (even to Jandali) until recently. When Steve Jobs died, there was an outpouring of tweets by Syrians mourning it, including "The wrong Syrian died today". The United States Embassy in Damascus posted this when he died 

"    Many people in America and around the world are mourning the death of Stephen Jobs from Apple. By all accounts, Stephen Jobs was a brilliant innovator and businessman. Not so many know that Stephen Jobs’ biological father was born in Homs, Syria’s third largest city, and studied at the American University in Beirut.

    Like all great leaders and innovators Jobs never let himself be poured into a mold. Rest in peace, Stephen Jobs, grandson of Homs.""]
results.description:
This is a city in Western Syria called Homs. It has been almost completely destroyed unfortunately, leading to thousands of deaths. 

There is very little going on for citizens of this godforsaken city. However, there was a small glimmer of pride for the citizens when the connection to this city with a world-famous person became known, whom some Syrians like to call "The most famous Arab of the world''. Who is that?

results.answer: Yes Suhas Pai.  It was James Garfield.  The only other President to be shot was in the first year of the 20th century - William McKinley, who died almost ten days later.   Siddhartha Sirsi is right too.  Sterilization of instrument was a new concept.  When Garfield was shot the doctors immediately probed the wound in an attempt to dislodge the bullet.  Of course, they did not follow any sterile precautions.  After he was brought to the White House the surgeons made several more  attempts to remove the bullet, undoubtedly introducing infection (ironically, the bullet did not have to be removed at all).
results.comments: ["C must be James Garfield, going by the 'late 19th century' and the 'lingered for months' clues, (thus ruling out Lincoln).","Washing hands and use of sterile instruments?","Yes Suhas Pai.  It was James Garfield.  The only other President to be shot was in the first year of the 20th century - William McKinley, who died almost ten days later.   Siddhartha Sirsi is right too.  Sterilization of instrument was a new concept.  When Garfield was shot the doctors immediately probed the wound in an attempt to dislodge the bullet.  Of course, they did not follow any sterile precautions.  After he was brought to the White House the surgeons made several more  attempts to remove the bullet, undoubtedly introducing infection (ironically, the bullet did not have to be removed at all).","Who is (A)?  It should be easy now.","Joseph Lister....??","B is carbolic acid.. I remember reading this in biology classes..","Lister followed the principles laid down by Louis Pasteur.  I was looking for Pasteur as the answer for A.  But Aseem Mohammed has sown a doubt in my mind.  It could have been Lister who came to America to educate American surgeons.  My question was based on a book called \"Destiny of the Republic\" by Candice Millard that I had read a few years ago.  My memory may have failed me.  I will have to dig it up again and give you an accurate answer next week.  By the way, anyone wants to crack the question as to what other two discoveries that Louis Pasteur was famous for?","Pasteurization...","Aishwarya Kumar, if the answer to A is Lister the answer to B would be Carbolic acid.  If A is Louis Pasteur, the answer for B would be sterilization by heat or chemicals.  I am going away to Philadelphia for the weekend and the correct answer will have to wait till next week :)","Pasteurization is one of them, Aishwarya Kumar.  The pioneer work of Louis Pasteur, however was vaccine for Rabies.  He cured a young man with the vaccine and his fame shot to the stratosphere.","Oops!  Forgot to post follow up.  The man who was in the U.S. promoting his technique of sterilizing the instruments was Louis Pasteur (not Lister).  If American surgeons had heeded to Pasteur's advice a president's life could have been saved."]
results.description:
(A) was a brilliant European scientist in late 19th century who had made a discovery (B) that reduced infections in wounds specially after surgery.  He took his discovery on the road and had come to America to teach his technique to the American surgeons.  His theory that diseases and infections can be caused by tiny microscopic organisms was largely laughed off by American surgeons.

Soon a President (C) would be shot in Washington D C.  The surgeons inserted instruments and their fingers in contrary to the advice of the European scientist.  The result was that the President lingered for months, with festering wounds and fistula, before finally succumbing.

(A) was also known for two other discoveries, one of them was a truly pioneering work.

ID:  A, B and C

What other discoveries did A make?

results.description:
Another July 4th trivia:  

(X) was the president who went to a celebration at Washington Mall on July 4, in the year ____(A), where he ate raw fruit (cherries).  He and many of the attendees fell sick with diarrhea and fever.  Within a week (July 9) the president was dead.  However, rumors of his assassination had circulated insistently ever since his death.  

A hundred and forty years later his body was exhumed (upon the request by his family) and tested for poisoning.  The results were inconclusive but no clear evidence of arsenic poisoning was found.  The matter was finally put to rest.

He had participated in the Mexican American war prior to running for president (reluctantly) and was affectionately called __________(B)

ID (X)
Which year (A)?
What was he called by his fellow soldiers (B)?

The Maharaja, Y wanted to accede to Pakistan as he could get a better deal. But a Hindu kingdom joining Pakistan sounded absurd. Finally Y was cornered by the close aide of Vallabhai Patel,  W. Y did sign the instrument of accession but not before some theatrics, He held the gun on W's head and exclaimed him 'Dont betray he people of X'. Any ways after Independence he married a Muslim film actress Z, on whose life there is a Bollywood Movie. He along with Z died when he was contesting for the 1952 general election and his plane had a unfortunate crash.

ID X,Y,Z

Clue: its 2001 flim and the screenplay was written by Z's son from her first marriage.

EDIT: X is Jodhpur.

results.answer: Sandhya Srinivasan gets it.  The scholar was Shah Jahan's oldest son Dara Shikoh.  Unfortunately, he met an untimely death in the hands of his younger brother Aurangzeb.  Dara Shikoh was the legitimate heir to the throne but Aurangzeb with the help of his two other brothers Shah Shuja and Murad Baksh chased Dara Shikoh to the border of Afghanistan and killed him.  Of course, the two brothers were also eliminated later when Aurangzeb climbed the throne after placing his father on house arrest in Agra Fort (to stare at his masterpiece creation, the TajMahal, longing for his deceased, beloved wife Mamtaz Mahal).
results.comments: ["A is Bahadur Shah Zafar?","C  - the Upanishads. B - Akbar?  A - ?","Sandhya Srinivasan gets it.  The scholar was Shah Jahan's oldest son Dara Shikoh.  Unfortunately, he met an untimely death in the hands of his younger brother Aurangzeb.  Dara Shikoh was the legitimate heir to the throne but Aurangzeb with the help of his two other brothers Shah Shuja and Murad Baksh chased Dara Shikoh to the border of Afghanistan and killed him.  Of course, the two brothers were also eliminated later when Aurangzeb climbed the throne after placing his father on house arrest in Agra Fort (to stare at his masterpiece creation, the TajMahal, longing for his deceased, beloved wife Mamtaz Mahal).","Dara Shikoh was killed in 1659.  The translation of Upanishads to Persian had been completed two years earlier in 1657.  A copy was to brought to France, but only a century later it was translated to both French and Latin by Abraham Hyacinth Anquetil- Duperron.  French version was never published and the Latin version was a lot of incomprehensible jargon.  However, philosopher Schopenhauer found the essence of Upanishads even in the shoddy translation and rest is history...","These are amazing facts, Ulan Bator - not very well known either, I might add...."]
results.description:
(A) was the great grandson of one of India's greatest monarchs (B).  (A) was inevitably compared to (B) because of his demeanor and aspirations.  He was also a scholar in Sanskrit and Persian languages.  

His translation of (C) to Persian language was the first exposure of (C) to the western world.  It was translated again to Latin by a Frenchman a century after the death of (A).  

Called 'The Oupnek'hat,' it drew the attention of philosophers (Schopenhauer) and poets (Ralph Emerson, Walt Whitman, Henry David Thoreau) alike.

ID:  A, B and C

results.answer: X is Charki-Dadri. In 1996, it was home to the third most deadliest disaster in aviation history, when a Saudia aircraft collided with a Kazakhstan Airways aircraft. Dadri was the place where one of the oldest cement factories was set up, which was eventually closed along with several others, when the government decided it was simply not financially feasible to keep it running. The Charki-Dadri disaster unfortunately put the town in a very negative light, as some of the localites looted the dead bodies and stripped them off their jewellery and other valuables. The relatives of the dead were scourging the crash area all by themselves, as apparently the government workers were busy preparing a make-shift helipad so that H.D Devegowda, the then P,M could land there.

results.comments: ["The copyright issue where the photographer claimed that he owns the photo and asked Wiki to take it down. Wiki refused.\nBTW, this macaque grabbed a camera from a photographer and took a selfie.","Crazy little being :)","Yes. Copper paralyzes bacteria and that is the reason it is used in water pipes and in air conditioning ducts, especially after the outbreak of Legionnaires disease in Philadelphia in 1976 at the Bellevue-Stafford Hotel following a convention of the members of the American Legion.","A is not yet cracked...","A is Aluminium?","Brass??","Vikram finally got it! results.description:
Romans used this element (A) in their exuberant gastronomical adventures, and the pioneer American families kept it in milk jugs, while riding across the wilderness, not for safekeeping but to keep the milk from spoiling.  

The sixteenth century astronomer, Tycho Brahe, who lost his nose in a drunken duel in dim lights, was said to have ordered an artificial replacement made from this element (A).  However, the hapless Brahe’s body was exhumed by the archeologists and, surprisingly, he was found to have the artificial nose made of a different element (B), which also has medicinal value.

Though discounted as folk remedies in the past, now the scientists are finding a renewed interest in both (A) and (B) for their healing powers.  (A) is still used today to treat certain conditions.  (B) is used in conduits for water and air, the latter especially after a particular deadly disease (C) that killed many people at a conference in Philadelphia in 1976. 

There is a reason why the doorknobs and handrails are not made of wood in public areas.

ID:  A, B and C

results.answer: Rosetta Stone (found in a place called Rosetta - Rashid, today) has three scripts - Egyptian hieroglyphs, Demotic script and Ancient Greek. The last was easy to read as there were experts who could do so in the year 1800. It took two decades more to not only realize that all the scripts were transliteration of the same text (a decree by Ptolemy V, the Pharaoh in 196 B.C., when it was written) and then the Egyptian hieroglyphics was a script written of a phonetic language. Frenchman Jean- Francois Champollion expanded on the work of Englishman Thomas Young to completely decipher the hieroglyphics. It is believed that Rosetta Stone was part of a temple in the Middle Ages and was taken to build the fort in the 15th century by Mamluk Al-Ashraf Saif al- Din Qa'it Bey. When Napoleonic troops were rebuilding the fort the Rosetta Stone was found unceremoniously as part of a wall!

results.answer: Blarney stone is below the battlements of Blarney Castle (originally built in 1210), which when kissed bestows the gift of the gab and one will never be at loss for words. The word Blarney has been added to English lexicon and means flattery or cajolery: deceptive talk but harmless, nonetheless. The stone is located at the machicolation (gap in the floor from which objects like stones, hot oil etc. can be poured on the enemies) on the top of the castle. It is a great tourist attraction near Cork, Ireland.

results.answer: This is Newgrange in Ireland.  Built in 3200 B.C., it is older than the pyramids of Giza and the Stonehenge.  It is decorated with monolithic art.  The large stones were procured from a radius of fifty miles and it is still a wonder how they managed to transport those huge boulders over such a distance, uphill.  The huge mound was built to honor the ancestors and has a chamber with a dome in its interior.  The ceiling of the dome is reinforced with large flat stones.  A long passage of more than sixty feet leads to the chamber where a smoothed out large stone bowl is strategically placed.  Why?  Every year on the day of winter solstice (Dec 21), at sunrise, a ray of sunlight enters through the rectangular window above the door and reaches the stone bowl and without spilling over lingers there a few moments before receding slowly through the same passage!  A marvelous feat when one considers they had to to work with stone tools to build it.  (Though it was the beginning of Bronze Age, the workers at Newgrange only had tools made of stone).  It is the evidence of first instance where man has used astronomical calculations and perfected it.  (There is still debate whether Stonehenge, built a thousand years later used winter or summer solstice -or either).  Several other mounds like Knowth, Dowth etc. were built later but Newgrange is thought to the first of its kind.

results.description:
X was a sea captain credited with the discovery of the Northwest Passage.  He sailed in two ships with a crew of 128 in 1845 never to return.  Evidence showed that they were marooned without adequate clothing and food and had resorted to cannibalism.  Death, apart from hypothermia was also due to severe lead poisoning, pneumonia and survey.

Several search parties had attempted to find the ships which were lost at sea both in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries to no avail.  Only recently in 2014 one of the ships was found in deep freezing waters off the coast of Canada.

The find is of such importance that it is compared to the finding of Tutankhamun's tomb and treasures in Egypt.

(X) became a hero; a subject many songs, poems and documentaries.

ID: X
Bonus Q:  what were the names of the two ships and which one of them was found in 2014.

results.description:
In 1993, driven by fierce insistence on achieving double-digit annual profit growth, X called about 30 of X's U.S. distributors to a meeting. They told them they were expected to take huge new stocks of older Y--up to two years' worth--and they threatened to sever their distributorship ties if they refused. However, many distributors were assured verbally that they wouldn't have to pay for the  until they sold them. All but two agreed, allowing X to book an extra $23 million in sales in the final days of 1993. But not long into 1994, almost all of the unwanted Y came back to X. 
 Following a Businessweek investigation in 1994, the matter was investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission who declared it inappropriate and public administrative proceedings were instituted pursuant to Section 21C of the US Securities Exchange Act of 1934. 
 A classic case of what happens on blind pursuit of results, X is the company and Y is the product. There was also a related product, same company, same period, similar scheme but in Asia Pacific centered around HongKong. Give me X and Y.

results.answer: This is a picture of Russel Terrence Rebello, 33 year old resident of Mumbai who died after helping a lot of travelers.  He was a worker on the cruise ship who had been resting that day due to high fever.  He helped them with their life jackets and to get on lifeboats.  He even gave his own jacket to a passenger.  His name is the fourth up from the bottom on the left side of the plaque. results.comments: ["Gregor Mendel, Peas, inheritence, genetics","Great crack Samrat Gali.  Mendelian dominant and recessive genes helped explain heredity.  The debate was whether new species came into existence because of a painfully slow process of natural selection or from mutation of genes, a more rapid occurrence.  The scientific community was fiercely divided about this.  Mendel was an unsung hero while he was alive (just like Swiss scientist Friedrich Miescher, a contemporary, whose work led to discovery of DNA).","+12... Biology","Physics, chemistry and biology.  Fair and balanced, huh?","Just Perfect as long as there is no differnciation and integration ;)"]
results.description:
(A) was a German-speaking friar and an Augustinian monk.  He joined the Abbey not because he was a pious man but because it paid the bills.  He was eventually chosen the Abbot.   His interest was more for science rather than religion.  His fame was mostly posthumous as his life was full of scandals.  After his death his scientific papers were unceremoniously set on fire in order to eliminate all traces of their existence by his fellow monks in the Abbey.

A nature lover, his work mainly involved experimentation in the greenhouse at the Abbey with these (B).  He made astute observations that the results were always with a mathematical accuracy, a ratio of 3:1.  It took scientists many more years but his work was finally recognized (posthumously) for its brilliance and helped explain this phenomenon (C) more clearly.  It also paved the way to future work on (D), a new branch of science in early 20th century.

For years afterwards, his work was in conflict with Charles Darwin’s natural selection.  The scientists took sides and their arguments were often heated and even combative.

ID (A) and what are (B), (C) and (D)

results.answer: Ivan the Terrible(X) built the iconic St. basil's Cathedral at the Red Square in Moscow.  He earned the moniker "terrible" because of his erratic behavior.  He was known to go into rages and in his paranoia commit unmentionable crimes on a whim.  He killed his own son and heir to the throne following a tantrum.  The painting depicts a remorseful Ivan cradling his bleeding son's body in his arms.  On close up this painting clearly depicts the horror he feels for the heinous act he committed.  The long term effect was that his second son Feodor who was  feckless, unworthy of the throne was named successor.  He died childless.  Romanovs came to power and remained the rulers until the Bolshoi revolution of 1917.
results.comments: ["A is Tzar","I don't know X's name, but he would have a name ending with \"The Horrible\" or \"The Terrible\"","Both are correct.  Ivan the Terrible was the first Tsar of all Russians.","Here is the rest of the answer as no one seem to attempt it.  Ivan the Terrible built the iconic St. basil's Cathedral at the Red Square in Moscow.  He earned the moniker \"terrible\" because of his erratic behavior.  He was known to go into rages and in his paranoia commit unmentionable crimes on a whim.  He killed his own son and heir to the throne following a tantrum.  The painting depicts a remorseful Ivan cradling his bleeding son's body in his arms.  On close up this painting clearly depicts the horror he feels for the heinous act he committed.  The long term effect was that his second son Feodor who was  feckless, unworthy of the throne was named successor.  He died childless.  Romanovs came to power and remained the rulers until the Bolshoi revolution of 1917."]

results.answer: A - Angola, B - Gulla Coast, C - Quilombo , D - Ganga Zumba
results.comments: ["surprisingly nobody has answered yet!. i too dont know the answer:(","D = Ganga Zumba","A = Angola","C - Quilombo , which is Campo Alegre today","Strictly based on the Brazilian clues alone, so I do not know B.","TAAG Angola to this day carries the most passengers to Rio an Sao Paulo.","Great crack Suhas Pai.  I was getting antsy that the group was slipping a bit.  The escaped slaves in Brazil formed an independent colony called Quilombo dos Palmares or Angola Janga in 1605.  They were mainly slaves from Angola.  They consisted of many escaped slaves as well as freed slaves and some whites who were mainly running away from conscription and mandatory military services.  They fortified their camps with walls and trenches.  They elected their leader Ganga Zumba who later built a palace and had three wives.  He was considered the king of Palmares (current day Alabaster state in Brazil).  In 1678 he was poisoned by his nephew Zumbi in protest because Ganga Zumba had signed a peace treaty with the Portuguese.","The coast of South Carolina and Georgia along with Sea Island (numbering about 100barrier islands) are inhabited by slaves who came from the region of Angola and Sierra Leone.  It is called the Gullah Coast (perhaps a twist on Angola).  They still speak an African language and their names still resemble names from Sierra Leone.  Isolation occurred because the white owners moved away leaving just a skeleton crew to manage the rice fields because of Malaria and Yellow fever the slaves had brought with them.  Some living in the islands after emancipation had no contacts with the white man or the mainland their entire lives until bridges were built after WWII.  So the answer to (B) is Gullah Coast.  The people are also called  Gullah people with Gullah language."]
results.description:
Talking about slavery in the Americas some more....

Most of the slaves from this country ( A) came to this coast today called (B) coast in North America.  The name (A) is a twist on the name of the country in Africa.  Some remnants of the culture and language are still retained here.

Early in the 17th century in Brazil, (where slaves had a lot more freedom) the slaves from the country (A) built an independent colony (C) of 10,000 strong for sometime before the Portuguese conquered them in 1694.  They chose their own leader, who had a name (D) reminding one of a well known river in India.

ID - A, B, C and D

I will post some pictures of inside the church soon."]

results.description:
The story of X begins in Padua, Italy in 1709, in the shop of a harpsichord maker named Bartolomeo di Francesco Cristofori. Many other stringed and keyboard instruments preceded X and led to the development of the instrument as we know it today. The earliest of these were dulcimer which led to the development of the clavichord, then followed by the spinet, virginal, clavecin, gravicembalo, and finally, the harpsichord in the 15th century. First exhibited in Florence in 1709, Bartolomeo's earliest surviving X dates from 1720 and is on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City.

results.comments: ["Yes, it is. Now to the trivia part. What is he doing here?","Mohandas Gandhi, founder of Passive resistors football club in South Africa","^^Wikipedia copy-paste?","Thanks you Rajan Singh It was hard for us to google /s","Rajan Singh Please read the rules of our group available on the sidebar!","@all I think  @Rajan did not google answer, but  the description.","The answer is the description. The question was \"give story\".","Might I raise a basic doubt? So what must one do if they do not know the answer- try to Google, learn more and keep it to themselves? Because somebody else would have known it through various other sources (including but not limited to Google) and want to see if they can recollect?","Yes Do google but dont spoil it for others","As much I think that is unfair, Okay cool.","Rajan Singh Narendra Pai Here is how it works: Quizzing has a gaming element to it, and is inherently competitive. Googling destroys the competitive premise, because basically anyone can Google, right? As for not sharing knowledge, every question here is eventually resolved, so you will know the answer in time. Everyone is free to Google to find out the answer, but please don't post it because it steals the satisfaction from some one who knows the answer. I am glad for your display of interest in the questions, but as a community we also need to respect the thrill that people get when they know an answer to a question, and did not have to find it.","Narendra Pai, No, this is not unfair. Quizzing is not about sharing knowledge at all! If that was the case, we wouldn't be asking questions - we would be just sharing tidbits of information","Suhas Pai, I conceded with \"okay cool\" which means I do not agree but I know there's really no point in this. What you think about Quizzing and its spirit might be your opinion and everybody else's. For me that definition doesn't quite fit. I read questions here to know the answers, I think it's okay to be courteous to that kind of crowd too- the one that occupies your audience chairs and idolises you just because you know the answer or that awesome trivia. But if it's not possible, it's really nobody's loss. Rules are rules and shall be followed.","Rajan Singh He is my brother but we do not share the same mother :-)","Narendra Pai  If you are reading questions here to know the answers (like most of us), you shouldn't really be concerned because every question is eventually answered! If no one answers it I usually prompt the QM to post a clue or the answer.","Piesauce, fair but be courteous to everybody, doesn't hurt (much). Reprimanding someone for googling, bit too much of elitism now. Most of us haven't had the chance to attend many quizzes, most of us are just too much in awe over the questions and we do wait for someone to answer but when the quizzards go all patronizing for merely googling it's a bit dejecting. I'm sure there's place for this perspective in a diverse group as GM.","Narendra Pai  Actually you are re-enforcing non-existent elitism in the group by distinguishing yourself from other 'quizzards'.  Everyone has an equal chance of answering or working out a question. Most questions here can be 'worked out'. Someone could guess the fact about Gandhi and football clubs by just observing the pic and making deductions. If one could not guess it, it does not mean they are a bad quizzer, it just means this question was meant for someone else. Googling is equivalent to plagiarism, because it reduces the incentive for QM's to form questions. Why will anyone waste 15 minutes of his/her time forming questions when someone is gonna Google it in a single minute anyway?\n\nI reject your allegation of not being 'courteous' enough. In fact, it is the other way round, because I find it disappointing that you choose to dissociate yourself from \"quizzards'', whoever they may be. I believe we are all on the same level, and I find no evidence to the contrary :-)","Somebody pressed the wrong button...hahha","Suhas Pai We cannot be on same level when there is one definition of quizzing that we have to adhere to. If this were a private group I wouldn't have used the word elitism. This offers to be an open group. Such rigidity and sarcasm for merely googling is what bothered me. I stand by my point that there cannot be one way to look at quizzing just because it is most exciting or whatever. There are other humans in this group too, nobody distances themselves deliberately, it's a reaction. I've grown tired of reading people mock somebody for googling and things. I had to put this out here as I saw nobody is interested in adding to the trivia- an anecdote they read or something. If the entire focus is on how a question should be cracked and what is the absolute way to do it, it is wrong.","You and anyone else is welcome to add as much anecdotes as you want, but only after the question is cracked. You are also free to have any definition of quizzing in your mind - but remember this, if we allow a free pass to Google, the quality of questions is gonna drastically come down. I for one, am not going to waste 15 minutes of my time to frame a question if someone is going to Google the heck out of it, and I know most QM's will not too! If you want a group where people just share useful tidbits of info, they are plenty around or you can create one on your own :-)","Yet you reject the idea of not being courteous, sure.","Courtesy has been extended to everyone, but you chose to reject it by not trying to understand my reasoning and going off on a different tangent :-)","Rules can be repeated. There's no need to mock. And there was mocking here.","I do apologize on behalf of whoever was mocking. Mocking is condescension, I agree whole-heartedly.","Okay.  I think we have established the fact here that the idea is not to score points by answering fast.  The quizzes on grey matter after different than in a competition where the first answer gets marks.  For me, it is exciting to ponder on a question and tickle the 'grey matter' inside my head a bit (create a sort of endorphin rush).  Once a googled answer is posted it is a dead end.  Anyone can google and get the answer instantly but one should admit that it does spoil the fun for others.  Knowledge needs to be imparted to everyone but discussing a question (as in answering and elaborating, even if it is the wrong answer) is 'food for thought' - as the cliche' goes.  So google if you want to when you are thirsty for information but hold off discussing until there is more input from others.  Okay?  Now let us all take a deep breath and have some fun...."]

I've flown quads that are rendered incapable of staying in the air for a long distance away from the controller (that receives and transmits signals). \n\nMost of the academia thinks this is bs.","But yes this was a concept ad that had a quad rotor that was human controlled at best.","Well, additionally drones are being used today by insurance companies to check the property, claims etc. Drones have an immense potential and they wouldn't replace pony mail but would provide an efficient and effective additional distribution line.","When this was first announced the general consensus was that this was pure bull.  To everyone's surprise Amazon is seeking permission to proceed with this.  They do admit that it years away from realizing it.  Amazon is also hiring and has advertised for at least six new jobs for engineers to develop and advance this technology.  So I wouldn't say never.  After all the law enforcement agencies are already using drones in many cities.","This makes sense to them... its not bullshit... it lets them replace manual labour and hence reduce operating costs involved in delivery. This wont be restricted to just ads...","Of course. I'm not saying this won't be possible. But there's still a few years of research left to implement what they've advertised. It's not yet ready. results.description:
This ornately carved and colossal warship was launched in the 17th century was the pride of King Gustavus Adolphus.  The king's subordinates did not have the courage to tell the ambitious king, who was in the midst of fighting "The Thirty Year War," that the ship had structural problems..  It was too top heavy.  It sank in its maiden voyage when it encountered a strong breeze in X harbor after sailing only for twenty minutes.  It was salvaged and brought up in 1961.  Despite being submerged for 333 years, it was found to be surprisingly in good shape, with a wealth of artifacts and about fifteen skeletons.  

What is the name of this battleship?  
Where is X?
Where is it today?

(Sorry, the picture does not do justice.  It is so large that it does not fit even in a wide-angled lens, especially the height of the ship which is impressive).

results.answer: Wailing wall, Jerusalem
results.comments: ["Wailing wall, Jerusalem","Sure, Siddhartha Sirsi.  If anyone does not recognize this, he/ she should take a long deep breath.  It is the wailing wall where Jews pray outside the Temple Mount.  The wall is what is remaining of the outer wall of the Temple Mount built by Herod, the Great just before the birth of Jesus.  The wall was not a sacred place of worship during the lifetime of Jesus.  Jesus prayed (especially during Passover holidays) in the glorious temple built by Herod, where the the Jewish sanctum sanctorum called the Holy of the Holies stood.  The dome with golden tiles is the Dome of the Rock, an Islamic holy site.  Most experts think that the site of Holy of the Holies is where the Islamic mosque Dome of the Rock stands today (though there is no archeological proof).  The Temple Mount and Herod's temple were destroyed by the Romans in 70 AD, some 40 years after the crucifixion of Jesus.  Jews haven't prayed in the Temple Mount since then but pray at the wailing wall, which is the remnant of the outer wall the  brilliant builder Herod the Great had constructed.  There are no other surviving parts of Herod's masterpiece except for the monumental foundation stones below the wailing wall that one can see in a tunnel under the wall.  Bonus question:  when and who made the dome golden?  Why is it called the Dome of the Rock?","Sala ud din? One of the stones from Kaaba is housed there?","Saladin had little to do with it.  The rock in Jerusalem (which predates the Stone of Kaaba by 2500 years) is believed to be where Abraham laid his son in order to sacrifice him upon the instruction of God.  The gold tiles were added to the dome in the 20th century by King Hussein of Jordan (father of the current King Abdullah)."]

They cared crap about the ones they shot and killed, of course...","I simply am never able to get past these questions without feeling horrible thinking about these times and people (and of course without even attempting to answer).","I guess you are sensitive to visual imagery then :-)","Why were communists executed in Germany","In 1919 the German communists tried to establish a communist state in Bavaria. It ended in a bloody struggle","Communism was anathema to Fascist Germany, though in 1919 fascism had not taken a firm hold yet in Germany.  Communism had just been established in USSR after WWI and Germany had suffered a humiliating defeat.  Anti-communist sentiments ran deep.  Rise of Fascism (first introduced by Mussolini in Italy in 1922) was rapid in Germany after 1932 following the Great Depression.  One of the stated goals of fascism in Hitler's Germany (apart from dealing with Jews) was to eliminate Communists.  In the end the only difference between totalitarian communism and fascism was possession of private property.  Communism confiscated private property and fascism supported it.  There is no difference when it comes to surveillance of citizens, eliminating political dissenters by mock trial (if that) and enforcement by military and paramilitary government forces.","Look at defiance of comrade","Vigneshwar Shankar Poojar It was staged for the photo","ahhh","How learning just the fact that it's a staged snap both gives a sense of relief and dilutes the horror of the real act at the same time. :P","And that's why, Narendra Pai, you must not watch game of thrones :D","Hahaha! results.description:
(A) is the most common word in the English language accounting for 7% of all words.  In any given text (A) appears twice as often as the second most common word (B) and three times as often as the third most common word (C).  Taking it further, (A) appears hundred times as often as the hundredth most common word and so on…

This phenomenon was first discovered by (X), a linguist and professor of German at Harvard University.  First, he counted words in James Joyce’s Ulysses and found the pattern (which came to be known as _____(X)_____’s Law.  It held true for other languages like Sanskrit, Hindi, Spanish, Russian languages, and even for hieroglyphics.  (X) found it even in the Sears catalogue!  

When extended to musical notes of Mozart or Chopin, the phenomenon was still found to exist.

What are A, B and C?

ID X and his Law.

results.answer: Children's Crusade
results.comments: ["was it the children's crusade?","Yes."]
results.description:
What started in 1213 when two monks decided to raise children in orphanages in France and Germany before sending them to North Africa? 

Almost 30000 children joined the program, thinking they were going to Palestine. Pope Innocent III also believed the same and commented, "These children are awake while we are asleep!" 

Most of the children were eventually shipped out of Marseilles but about half drowned in shipwrecks enroute. Most of the remaining got to North Africa. 

Several ships carrying the children landed at Genoa due to a misunderstanding. The children disembarked but found there was no connecting ship to take them further. The people of Genoa kindly gave them some money and sent them back to France unwittingly saving them from the fate that awaited their colleagues in North Africa.

results.description:
The Japanese Peace Bell is a United Nations peace symbol. Cast on November 24, 1952, it was an official gift of the Japanese people to the United Nations on June 8, 1954. 

The symbolic bell of peace was donated by Japan to the United Nations at a time when Japan had not yet been officially admitted to the United Nations. 

The Japanese Peace Bell was presented to the United Nations by the United Nations Association of Japan.

Infrequently this bell is tolled on special occasions but every year on a regular basis it is tolled twice
Once during the UN General Assembly’s yearly session .
On WHAT OTHER DAY IS IT TOLLED EVERY YEAR ??

results.description:
BEG YOUR PARDON AS THIS IS A PRETTY LENGTHY ONE 

For a long time X says that he had been aware of the fact that people were more likely to favor someone who was less than perfect. X says in one of his interviews …………………….

It's a safe bet that you remember Quasimodo, but how easily can you name any of the heroic, handsomer, more glamorous characters in The Hunchback of Notre Dame?

And then there's Frankenstein... I've always had a soft spot in my heart for the Frankenstein monster. No one could ever convince me that he was the bad guy.... He never wanted to hurt anyone; he merely groped his torturous way through a second life trying to defend himself, trying to come to terms with those who sought to destroy him. ...

I decided I might as well borrow from Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde as well — our protagonist would constantly change from his normal identity to his superhuman alter ego and back again.

And thus Inspired by them all , X created Y .

results.answer:
Einstein and his brain!  The hospital where his brain was pickled was Princeton Hospital where the pathologist Thomas Stoltz Harvey was working (and famously purloined the brain without the knowledge of the family).  To everyone’s surprise the brain weighed an average of 1230 grams giving credence to the famous adage that ‘size does not matter!’

Multiple sections of the brain were made, like the pathologists are wont to do.  But over the next fifty years no particular useful information could be discerned from studying it.  The pathologist kept the sectioned brain pieces (46 pieces in all) unceremoniously in a mason jar in a closet next to a beer cooler for several decades. 

In 1978 an astute reporter got wind that the pathologist had Einstein’s brain in his lab and this created a minor sensation.  Reporters were camped in front of his house for days.  

In 2010, the family of Einstein repossessed all the pieces of brain, and donated it to National Museum of Science and Medicine.  There were also 14 photographs that no one knew about.

Recently, all 46 fragments were acquired by Mütter Museum of Medical Oddities, in Philadelphia.  In 2013 all the slices were mounted on microscopes and were put on permanent exhibit in its galleries for public view.

Only recently a restudy of the brain has shown some strong connections between the left and right hemispheres and an increase in the glial cells.  If this was proof enough to brand the brain belonged to a genius has not been settled.

results.description:
I love this story.  Should be an easy one:

After his death scientist (A) remained in the public eye for his unprecedented discoveries as well as for other more morbid reasons.  He had considered donating his organ (B) for research but then changed his mind and left explicit instructions to his family about it.  He did not want the organ to be elevated to sanctimonious status, like the Christian relics of medieval years.

However, when his body was returned after a routine autopsy (he had died from a ruptured aneurysm with internal bleeding), the pathologist (C) in the prestigious  (D) University purloined (B) without permission from the family.  Unbeknownst to them, the family members dutifully cremated the body of (A).

The following day, the young son of the pathologist (C) was seen bragging in class that his father had (A)’s organ with him!  News spread like wildfire and the newspapers spilled much ink on the headlines the next morning.  The pathologist apologized to the family and settled with them but kept the organ (B) for experimental purpose.

ID:  A, B, C and D

results.description:
A bit too long, But an interesting one.

The year was 1982. X had probably pulled off the greatest upset in the history of international football. X won 2-1 against Y who were the giants of football at that period of time. X lost their second game 2-0 to Austria and won their third game against Chile. It was clear that for Y to proceed, they needed to beat Austria by a  one- or two-goal margin, then both these sides would make it through to the next round. Y scored in the 10th minute of the game and then having having realized that the scoreline would help them both, both Y and Austria stopped trying to make any more inroads, instead just killing time for the next 80 minutes. 

The X fans in the stands cried foul, claiming that the much-evident match-fixing had robbed them of a dream chance to join the qualify past the first round of the World Cup.

No action was taken by FIFA on either Y or Austria. But they made an important decision after this incident. What was the decision and what is this incident infamously known as? ID X & Y.

results.answer:
Obama made a trip to Karachi when he was 20 years old. While at Columbia University, Obama used to share a room with a Pakistani called Sohale Siddiqi. During the vacations, Obama went on a three week trip to see his buddy and his family.

This looks cool, but Obama's opponents used this is as evidence that Obama is not a U.S citizen. The reasoning used was that in 1981, Pakistan was on the US's "no-fly" list, and hence he could have gone there only if he had an Indonesian or a British (since his father was Kenyan) passport. Moreover, Obama never mentioned this trip in any of his books. The first time he publicly talked about this trip was in 2008.

It was later proved that there was no such "no-fly" advisory for Pakistan at that time; and Obama could freely go there while being a US citizen.

It is in UK (Northern Ireland).  UK refers to Great Britain and Northern Ireland together.  Great Britain per se includes England, Scotland and Wales.  Before Republic of Ireland gained independence in 1922, UK was called United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.  After 1922 it is called United Kingdom of of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.  Meanwhile England is part of Great Britain without Scotland and Wales.  In addition British Isles refer to both Great Britain and the entire island of Ireland (inclusive of both Northern Ireland and Republic of Ireland) along with smaller islands like Isle of Man, Bailiwick of Jersey and Channel Islands.  The latter islands are not part of UK but are Dependencies of the Crown.  Then there are the British Commonwealth countries, which are former colonies.  (Too many to enumerate here).  Confused?"]

results.answer:
Mr. Wrestling was the only face (good guy) in the plane crash. The rest of the wrestlers in the plane crash were heels (bad guys). Kayfabe (keeping the impression that wrestling is real) was big in those days, so the wrestling promotion had to do everything possible to prevent the public from knowing that Mr. Wrestling was traveling along with the bad guys.

But then some newspapers had already published that Mr. Wrestling was in the plane crash and was seriously injured. Hence, to protect wrestling kayfabe, Mr. Wrestling performed a heroic act and wrestled in a match even though he was in intense pain, to prove that he wasn't traveling with the heels.

results.description:
Mr. Wrestling was a famous 20th century pro-wrestler. In the 1970's he was involved in a plane crash that also included wrestlers like Ric Flair. He was seriously injured in the crash and was in a whole lot of pain, yet two weeks later he wrestled in a match. Because of this action, pundits called him "the man who saved wrestling". 
Why was it so imperative for him to wrestle even though he was in so much pain?

Different cultures rely on different human characteristics in order to 'predict the future' or 'prepare a horoscope'. We are well aware of sun signs and birth time/place being used as a basis for preparing horoscopes. In Japanese culture, some other human characteristic is prominently used in horoscopes/predictions etc.

In fact, Facebook Japan has a field in the profile where you can enter this particular human characteristic. This characteristic is even used by school children to bully each other, and the Japanese government has discouraged employers to ask about this information from candidates. What are we talking about?

X is the term used to refer to an ancient Greek ritual. This ritual usually was performed by mystery religions, which were not public and needed an initiation to get into. The Romans viewed this ritual with great suspicion and tried to suppress it. 

Today, the ritual is still alive, and is no longer restricted to Greece. However, it still (in part) retains its exclusive nature. It is also a popular sub genre in a particular genre of movies. In English, X also means excess or overabundance. ID X

results.answer: You are correct.  She was born Maria Eva Duarte and was the second wife of President Juan Peron of Argentina.  She had met Colonel Peron as a young aspiring actress and became his second wife in 1945.  She championed labour causes, women's suffrage and created a female Peronist party.  She portrayed a saintly figure when she visited the poor and the needy and demonstrated a genuine affection for the sick.  She died an untimely death at age 33 from metastatic cervical cancer in 1952.  Prior to that she had to withdraw as vice presidential candidate due to ill health.  After her death her body was embalmed and a memorial was being built in Buenos Aires when her husband was overthrown by military coup d'état.  Her body was secretly taken to Europe and buried in Milan (an unknown location).  The military feared she would be looked upon as a martyr and rile up the emotions of ordinary people.  Later Evita's embalmed body was exhumed and brought to Juan Peron's home in Spain in 1971, where he and his third wife Isabel had it displayed on a platform in the dining room.  In 1973 Peron became president for the third time and came back from exile to Argentina.  But he died the next year and Isabel succeeded him as the first female president of the Western Hemisphere.  She had Evita's body brought back to Buenos Aires and had her displayed next to Juan Peron's body briefly.  Then she was buried in la Recoleta cemetery where a mausoleum was built with great security with two solid trap doors.  Poor Evita (don't cry for me Argentina) finally found her final resting place after journeying for almost twenty years after her death.
