results.answer: nijyuu hibakusha survived both the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings. (because thousands escaped hiroshima and went to nagasaki after the first bomb). hibakusha is an ordinary survivor - survived only one of the bombings.
results.comments: ["Hiroshima?","nijyuu hibakusha survived both the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings. (because thousands escaped hiroshima and went to nagasaki after the first bomb). hibakusha is an ordinary survivor - survived only one of the bombings. I don't know Japanese (although I like to claim I do). \"\"still suffered from compromised immune system \" was the giveaway","konichiwaa","Raku deshita, Suhas Pai.  Domo arigato.  The name of the lone nijyuu hibakusha is Tsutomu Yamaguchi.  He was on the field within 1-5 miles of the hypocenter at Hiroshima.  Badly burnt and vomiting, he managed to go home to his wife and infant son in Nagasaki, where his boss in Nagasaki refused to believe his story.  He found himself again near the hypocenter of another bombing three days later.  The \"little boy\" of Hiroshima had failed to elicit immediate Japanese surrender and hence Americans used the \"fat boy\" on Nagasaki, which had the desired effect.  The feared genetic mutation did not occur in the following generations, however.  Members of Yamaguchi's family died from cancer but the incidences could be age related.  His two daughters were born after 1945 and did not suffer any genetic diseases, though they claimed their health issues on both their parents being hibakusha...","Oh, \"nijyuu hibakusha\" literally means \"twice bombed.\"  Hibakusha were those who were within a radius of 2 kilometers of the hypocenter in any one of the two disaster areas.  150 unfortunate folks were exposed to the bomb twice though Japan recognized only one, Tsutomu Yamaguchi.  \"Little boy\" killed 80,000 and \"fat boy\" killed 70,000 Japanese people, not counting the long time effects on environment, water supply etc.","Isn't it Fat Man?","Yup its fat man","I stand corrected.  \"Fat man\" it is!  More appropriate name (sinister sounding) than \"little boy,\" wouldn't you agree?","Agreed (Y)","Doesn't Nijyuu mean twenty?","Yes.  It also means \"double\" as far as I can tell :)"]
results.description:
(X) was an engineer at Mitsubishi.  He was the only person officially identified by the government in Japan as nijyuu hibakusha (there were about 150 of them altogether).  Comparatively there were hundreds of thousands of hibakusha (including his wife and son).

 He died at the ripe old age of 93 in 2010 from cancer of the stomach.  He outlived both his son and wife.  His only son died of cancer at age fifty-eight. The wife died of cancer of kidney and liver.  

His two daughters who were not hibakusha still suffered from compromised immune system but lived full lives.  They both claimed health issues directly as a result of their parents being hibakusha.

ID X
What do the terms nijyuu hibakusha and hibakusha mean?

(I expect very few of the members to know Japanese but I thought that the fact that the terms have made their appearances in the English print media is interesting.  Nevertheless, it is an easy quiz to solve with minimal clues, I think).

results.description: Roosevelt was once invited to a hunting trip. Most of the hunters competing had already killed an animal. A suite of Roosevelt's attendants cornered, clubbed, and tied an animal to a willow tree after a long exhausting chase, called Roosevelt to the site and suggested that he should shoot it. He refused to shoot it himself, deeming this unsportsmanlike, but instructed that it should be killed to put it out of its misery. It became the topic of a political cartoon by Clifford Berryman in The Washington Post on November 16, 1902. While the initial cartoon figured an adult animal, later issues of that and other Berryman cartoons made the animal smaller and cuter. • What got its name after this incident?

results.description:
(A) was a Dutchman, a seafaring explorer, who set out in 1594 to see if there was a northern route to Asia, specifically to China.  With his ship Mercury he tried to circumnavigate a land mass called (X).  No one was sure if this was a promontory of a new undiscovered continent or a mere island.

For 1500 miles he navigated its western shore, heading north, his ship dodging many armadas of floating ice, foiling disaster only to turn back at the behest of his frazzled crewmembers.  A second attempt a year later also ended in mutiny and he had to retreat.

But the third time in 1596 was charm (or was it?)  His ship traveled north and rounded the northern coast of the island (yes, it was not an undiscovered continent but an island) only to be marooned by ice again.

The crew had to abandon ship and winter on the northeast coast of the (X), building a cabin out of salvaged wood from the ship.  For food they hunted polar bears (polar bears also were trying to hunt the sailors), but consumption of (Y) – an organ of the polar bear - produced a disease (Z) from which most of them including (A) perished.

The sea he navigated bears his name today (B)?

The island (X) was used in the 20th century for nuclear testing by (C).

Who was this daring explorer (A)?  What is the sea (B) named after him?

ID: A, B, C, X, Y and Z

results.answer: (A) is Gunottam Hutheesing, who was married to Krishna Nehru (B), sister of Jawaharlal (C).  Gunottam belongs to a well known Jain family from Ahmedabad.    His disagreement with Jawaharlal and the Congress party platform led to the formation of Swatantra Party by C. Rajagopalachari (X).  Their son Ajit Hutheesing (D) is the entrepreneur who has a successful career in Wall Street. results.answer: Hiram Bingham III was educated in Yale, UC Berkely and Harvard.  He also taught in Harvard (history and politics) and in Princeton.  He was appointed by Yale as lecturer in South American history.  He was one of the first to have discovered the long forgotten Machu Picchu in aperçu.  The government of Peru claimed that he had taken 40,000 artifacts (originally it was thought that number was 4000).  That would make this not a theft but a heist!

Who was the culprit who purloined the artifacts for '18 months?\"","Hiram Bingham","Yes.  Hiram Bingham III was educated in Yale, UC Berkely and Harvard. results.description:
(X) brought ceramic vessels, silver statues and jewelry, and human bones in 1914-15 to Yale University for further study.  (X) was credited with re-discovering the place (Y) in country (A), where these treasures were found.

The original agreement was to keep the artifacts for study for 18 months but Yale kept all of them and even exhibited them in its museum, refusing to return them to country (A).  The excuse was that the country did not have the infrastructure to care for the pieces.

A wife of former president of country (A), an anthropologist, started demanding that Yale return those artifacts to country (A) national heritage, in 2006.  After litigation, Yale had to return all the artifacts in 2012 (almost hundred years after they were ‘stolen’).

Now they are permanently located in “The Shell House” in this city (B) in the country (A)

ID:  X and Y and the Country A, City B

(The Shell House is the English translation of the name for it in the local lingo)

results.description:
Interesting letter written more than
100 years back..
COMPLAINT LETTER TO THE RAILWAYS
IN 1909!!
Okhil Babu`s letter to the Railway
department:
Date: 02 - 07 - 1909
Divisional Railway Officer,
Sahibgunj,
Respected Sirs,
I am arrive by passenger train
Ahmedpur station and my belly is too
much swelling with jackfruit. I am
therefore went to privy. Just I doing
the nuisance that guard making whistle
blow or train to go off and I am
running with lotaah in one hand and
dhoti in the next when I am fall over
and expose all my shocking to man and
female women on platform. I am got
leaved at Ahmedpur station. This too
much bad, if passenger go to make
dung that dam guard not wait train
five minutes for him. I am therefore
pray your honour to make big fine on
that guard for public sake. Otherwise I
am making big report to papers.
(ORIGINAL LETTER)
Your faithful Servant,
Okhil Chandra Sen
Okhil Babu wrote this letter to the
Sahibganj divisional railway officer in
1909. It is on display at the Railway
Museum in New Delhi. It was also
reproduced under the caption
Travellers ales in the Far Eastern
Economic Review.
Any guesses why this letter is of
Historic Value?

results.answer: At the death of Pertinax, the whole Roman Empire was put up for sale by auction. Sulbician and Julian competed for it with Julian putting up the winning bid.
results.comments: ["Rosetta stone?","That's Julius Caesar. He bought the city of Rome?","Close enough! :)  At the death of Pertinax, the whole Roman Empire was put up for sale by auction. Sulbician and Julian competed for it with Julian putting up the winning bid.","Um but wasn't there something about per-person cost?","If there was, I don't know anything about it. If you do find out more, I will be glad for the info.","The original article I read about Julius Caesar was on the lines of how he bought Rome for 6250 drachmas per soldier. That's how I recognized the number. Not sure about the specifics :-o","Can't find any concrete info through googling. Any history experts here??","His death, in short","Neria Harish Hebbar, care to comment?","You may be confusing Didius Julianus with Julian who was an emperor in the later period.  Julianus bid for Rome and paid 6250 drachmas per soldier.  He was a rich Senator who outbid everyone else.  But he seemed to have had buyer's remorse when he found that governing was not a cakewalk.  The subversive acts, intrigue and treasonous plots caused him discomfiture, no doubt.  He was right about that because he was promptly executed by the Senate.  He was emperor only for two months.  Julian (also known as Julian the Apostle and Julian the Philosopher) was an emperor in the 4th century and ruled for three years.  He died from mortal wounds suffered in a battle against Sassanids (Persia).","Thanks for clearing that up! My apologies over the confusion, fellow members!","So everything is sorted out :)"]
results.description: In 193 AD, future Roman Emperor Julian attended an auction where he bought what for 6250 drachmas?

results.answer: A team of researchers from University College London (UCL) found that the action of the goalie is predictable after three kicks go in the same direction.  He leans to the other side on the fourth kick 69% of the time.  This is statistically significant predictability according to the study published in journal, Current Biology.  Psychologists studied videos of World Cup and European Championship from 1972 to 2102.  They, however did not study the middle though they found that the goalie stays in the middle only 2.5% of the time.  They suggested that kickers could exploit that by kicking in the middle more often.  Other conclusion was that none of the teams seem to have taken advantage of gambler's fallacy by deliberately kicking the fourth goal to the opposite side if the first three had gone in the one direction.  The pressure on the kicker is so great to deliver the best kick that the statistics and probabilities do not factor in the game plan.
results.comments: ["If you keep losing, you will eventually start winning. If you keep getting heads on a coin toss, you will eventually start getting tails. However, these events are independent and the probability of winning/getting tails still remains the same, hence the gambler's fallacy","You are correct about tossing the coin and probabilities Suhas Pai.  Wrong about soccer though.  Gambler's fallacy involves penalty kicks?  If you lose soccer games all the time you have a bad team!","Yes, I was wondering how would one apply the gambler's fallacy to penalty kicks :-)","Do I have the wrong term here?  What I mean is \"shoot outs\" to determine the game when I say penalty kicks.","Penalty kicks happen within game play time, shoot outs only after tie-game.","About the Coin, it would if and only if the coin was \"fair\"","I stand corrected Vigneshwar.  (Ihave been far removed from the game for too long).  The hybrid word is \"penalty shoot-out,\" I suppose.","So to rephrase the question: how does \"gambler's fallacy\" apply to penalty shoot-outs?","That if the ball is shot into one side most times it wil be eventually shot to the other side and the keeper can save atleast one or something if he keepa divin to one side only??","If multiple kicks were aimed at one end of the net then the goalkeeper would think that the next kick would be directed towards the opposite end.","Precisely Siddhartha Sirsi.  Sazi Suber is looking at it from a different angle!  A team of researchers from University College London (UCL) found that the action of the goalie is predictable after three kicks go in the same direction.  He leans to the other side on the fourth kick 69% of the time.  This is statistically significant predictability according to the study published in journal, Current Biology.  Psychologists studied videos of World Cup and European Championship from 1972 to 2102.  They, however did not study the middle though they found that the goalie stays in the middle only 2.5% of the time.  They suggested that kickers could exploit that by kicking in the middle more often.  Other conclusion was that none of the teams seem to have taken advantage of gambler's fallacy by deliberately kicking the fourth goal to the opposite side if the first three had gone in the one direction.  The pressure on the kicker is so great to deliver the best kick that the statistics and probabilities do not factor in the game plan.","Yeah just read it... :)","Lies, damn Lies and Statistics","http://econfix.wordpress.com/2014/03/11/game-theory-lesson-man-utd-v-chelsea-penalty-shootout/\nBeing a Manchester United fan that night gives me orgasms even today remembering watchin it live and seeing our Goalkeeper mess with Anelka...","Neria Harish Hebbar that link should interest this discussion since pressure does play a key role in the biggest of goof ups...","The slip"]

results.description:
From the page MICA Quiz Club

The 1979 vintage video game called X was designed and programmed by just one person, Warren Robinett who worked for the company Y. Back at the time, Y refused to give credit to its programmers for their work, so the name of the game's creator did not appear anywhere on the packaging. So Warren Robinett decided to hide his name inside the game where he hid a key in one of the game's labyrinths. If a player found the key, he would enter a secret room that would reveal the name of the creator. This feature was dubbed the first Z in the world. Name X,Y,Z.

results.answer: A is India, B is Jamaica, and X is Ganja , and Bob Marley wrote the songs! From the mid 1800s to around 1915, several ships carried Indians to the West Indies to work as indentured laborers. Workers from Uttar Pradesh and Bihar sailed through ships originating from Calcutta and workers from Tamil Nadu sailed through ships originating from Madras. The destinations were Trinidad, Jamaica, Guyana, and Suriname. The Uttar Pradesh folks introduced Ganja in these countries and the native population loved it! Cannabis is called as Marijuana in most parts of North America but the West Indies uses the desi name for it due to its origin. A century later, Bob Marley became a stereotypical icon for ganja due to his songs. This year, Jamaica legalized ganja. The ganja in jamaica is probably one of the cheapest in the world and jamaica is among the highest per capita ganja consumption in the world

results.description: In one of the longest immigration journeys in the world (in terms of distance), thousands of people from Country A migrated to B from 1848-1914. They introduced X to B and the natives were fascinated by it and adopted it in their culture. More than a century later, a native from B wrote popular songs about X and gained worldwide popularity, but especially in A. What is A, B, and X?

results.description:
X is a UK-based Community Interest Company established in 2012 and the brain-child of political artist, Manali Jagtap. X annually recognizes artworks that helps shape and inspire through visual arts how people and organisations understand, engage and respond to war, violent conflict and social upheaval. X  awards art works and art projects that make a direct positive change in countries which have experienced war, violent conflict and social upheaval. The award Y is announced during the week of International Peace Day each year and is currently a GBP 2500 cash prize. The award Y is designed by London-based wood artist Sebastian Cox. South African photographer Alexia Webster is the first recipient of Y.
ID X and Y(the award).

I just went on a morning walk today and I saw a celebrity (or atleast his doppelganger) in one of the cafes. This is not too uncommon. Tons of celebrities visit Amsterdam and chill out in the "coffee shops". In fact, one of the most popular movies ever was written in a coffee shop called the Betty Boop, when the writer/director spent several months in Amsterdam "on a break". As a result, this movie contains several cultural references to Amsterdam.

Which movie and who is the director/writer? Bonus points for pointing out the cultural references in the movie.

results.description:
In Japanese culture it is widely believed that X brings good luck to thousands of high school students who sit for their entrance examinations to gain an admission into Japan's top universities because co-incidentally X in Japanese translates to "You shall surely win" or "Be Victorious". 

Y (manufacturers of X) responded to this fortuitous linguistic association by producing for the Japanese market special types of X that carry additional exam-related symbols on their packaging. 
 
Also when the Japan Postal service was being privatized, Y seized an  opportunity and created a business model that didn't exist before. Y partnered with the newly privatized post office and created a new  package of X that could be posted, called X Mail. People could write their message on the packaging, put a stamp on it and put it in the mail. Many post office branches during exams decorate their stores with X branding which has now become a part of their culture.  

X and Y?

results.answer: John Adams was ninety years old when he died on July 4, 1826.  His one time adversary and then a friend also was living his last days in Monticello.  What Adams did not know when he made the comment, "Thomas Jefferson lives!" was that the eighty-two year old Jefferson had already passed five hours earlier.
